comments.body:
Looking at the `setup.py` file, there are two "extra" dependencies: 
- PyOpenSSL to support ftps. This library is available via the `default` channel, so it seems sensible to include it. 
- pysendfile to speed up uploads on posix for speeding up uploads for python <3.3. This is not on `defaults` or `conda-forge`, so I'm less inclined to add it at this point (but maybe it could be added in the feedstock once a conda-forge recipe is added).

We do not have a clear policy on "extra" (optional) dependencies. I usually add those that I believe are important. Since I am not a user of `pyftpdlib` I cannot say anything about `PyOpenSSL`. Do you have any strong reason to request that @synapticarbors?

I am not a user of `pyftplib` either and I don't have a strong feeling about including the extras or not. It just seemed simple to add PyOpenSSL given it's availability and that it provided a more secure protocol.

Sure, I can add the `PyOpenSSL` dependency. Seems very reasonable.
I'm not sure about `pysendfile` since `conda-forge` doesn't build packages for py<3.3, but only for py 2.7. In this case it would only make sense to add the dependency for py 2.7, however, I'm not a huge fan of having libraries too different from each other (py 3 and py 2).

Another fact I noticed about `pysendfile` is that it is not supported on windows. Its [readme](https://github.com/giampaolo/pysendfile) says:

> This module works with Python versions from 2.5 to 3.4. The supported platforms are:
> - Linux
> - Mac OSX
> - FreeBSD
> - Dragon Fly BSD
> - Sun OS
> - AIX (not properly tested)

So no windows there, nor Python 3.5.

FWIW am adding `pysendfile` in PR ( https://github.com/conda-forge/staged-recipes/pull/7375 ).

They since support newer Python 3 versions.

Windows is still not supported. Though it does seem to be something they are interested in. They just need a bit of help. ( https://github.com/giampaolo/pysendfile/issues/30 )
